H0.text: Igneous rock has turned into sedimentary rock in a land area where a rock formation originally contained fossils and, after exposure to tremendous heat and pressure, produced a harder rock formation without fossils.

H1.text: Igneous rock has turned into metamorphic rock is the change in rock type that occurred in a land area where a fossil-containing rock formation was subjected to tremendous heat and pressure, producing a harder rock formation without fossils.

H2.text: Sedimentary rock has turned into igneous rock, a transformation that occurred in a land area where a rock formation containing fossils was subjected to tremendous heat and pressure, producing a harder rock formation without fossils.

H3.text: Sedimentary rock has turned into metamorphic rock in a land area that originally contained fossils, where tremendous heat and pressure changed the formation into a harder rock without fossils.

A4.text: Metamorphic rock can be formed locally when rock is heated by the intrusion of hot molten rock called magma from the Earth's interior.

A5.text: The protolith may be an igneous, sedimentary, or existing metamorphic rock.

A6.text: The metamorphic, igneous, and sedimentary rocks of the mountains become the new piles of sediments in the adjoining basins and eventually become sedimentary rock.

A7.text: As the two masses are compressed, folded and faulted into a mountain range by the continental collision the whole suite of pre-existing igneous, volcanic, sedimentary and earlier metamorphic rock units are subjected to this new metamorphic event.
